raw akas.title: How the States Got Their Shapes

akas: How the States Got Their Shapes (original title)
akas from release info: How the States Got Their Shapes (original title)

1.title: Red State vs. Blue State

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

1.plot: It's a rivalry that tears us apart every four years, but how did our nation divide into red states vs. blue states, and what happens to the states caught in the middle?

2.title: White Collar vs. Blue Collar

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

2.plot: Deep in the Rust Belt the white collar and blue collar divide has shaped our cities and our states. How did this rivalry change the way we all bring home the bacon?

3.title: Hillbilly vs. Redneck

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

3.plot: Two underdogs of American culture go head to head to prove how hillbillies and rednecks have shaped our states.

4.title: Hatfields vs. McCoys

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

4.plot: America's most iconic rivalry was more than just a feud between families. The fight between the Hatfields and McCoys nearly launched a war between two states.

5.title: Bigfoot vs. Aliens

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

5.plot: America is a nation under siege by unexplained phenomena. Whether you're afraid of Bigfoot or alien invasion might depend on what state you call home.

6.title: North vs. South

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

6.plot: It's America's original rivalry, a divide that was so wide it took a war to close the gap. But have we really reunited, or are we still fighting a culture war?

7.title: Great Lakes, Big Stakes

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

7.plot: Battles over access to lakefront property have made the Great Lakes region the most contested land on the entire map, and even pushed the states to a border war.

8.title: Battle of the Bible Belt

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

8.plot: With 85% of Americans affiliated with an organized religion, we're a nation of believers, but have we always practiced what we preached?

9.title: Vice vs. Virtue

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

9.plot: Americans have a lot of vices and they don't just stay in Vegas. From drugs to gambling, the state you live in may shape how bad you can be.

10.title: Midwest vs. The Rest

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

10.plot: It's the glue that holds our map together and feeds America, but the Midwest is more than just state fairs and flyover country.

11.title: Is West Best?

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

11.plot: In the battle between city and country, it looks like the city is coming out ahead in population, but is there something about the country that all the city slickers are missing?

12.title: City vs. Country

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

12.plot: The squabble between east coast and west coast leaves the rest of the country stuck in the middle. It's a rivalry that has made its way into our popular culture, but is there any common ground in this continental tug of war?

13.title: East vs. West

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

13.plot: We may be a law-abiding nation but we also admire the outlaw, and the clash between rebels and the rules has shaped our states. Which states like to make their own rules, and which do the heat have on lockdown?

14.title: Rebels & Outlaws

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

14.plot: Everything is bigger in Texas. It's the only state that acts like a country, but has it grown too big for its britches? We'll mess with Texas to settle this ten-gallon rivalry.

15.title: Mess with Texas

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

15.plot: Money makes the world go `round and in America, the pursuit of riches has shaped our states. In the race to grab all resources, which states came out on top?

16.title: State vs. State

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

16.plot: Does size matter when you're a state? While the giants like to throw their weight around, there are some scrappy underdogs that have made their mark on the map.

17.title: Rich vs. Poor

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

17.plot: After three years on the road, host Brian Unger is taking a different look at just how our states got their shapes. We'll hear about the unique American values that have made this country what it is today.

18.title: Big vs. Small

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

18.plot: Does size matter when you're a state? While the giants like to throw their weight around, there are some scrappy underdogs that have made their mark on the map.

19.title: The United Shapes of America

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

19.plot: How the States Got Their Shapes looks at how American values helped to make the country what it is today. In particular, it looks at how the values of independence, equality, enterprise, freedom, and competition helped to give the United States the shape that it has today.

1.title: A River Runs Through It

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

1.plot: How water has literally shaped the States. The surprising history hidden in the blue, squiggly lines on the map: How the founding fathers might have made a mistake along the Georgia Tennessee border; how that boundary could actually change because of water; why Maine has so much -- and why Nevada was left high and dry. All told the unique shapes of these states.

2.title: Great Plains, Trains, & Automobiles

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

2.plot: The history of transportation hidden in the lines of the map. From canals to trains and cars, how getting around helped draw the American map. Why Chicago could have been in Wisconsin; why states out West or so big and boxy; and why we almost had a state called Forgottonia.

3.title: Force of Nature

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

3.plot: How massive geological events helped create the American map. Long before the Founding Fathers drew the map, mother nature shape some states: how an asteroid created the border for three states and changed history; how glaciers plowed the great plains and how natural disasters continue to alter the map.

4.title: State of Rebellion

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

4.plot: How did the most rebellious states took shape? How did they earn their outsized features and outspoken reputations. For instance, why does Montana looks like it took a bite out of Idaho? Why wasn't Texas broken up into five states? And why exactly do we have not one but two Carolinas?

5.title: Living on the Edge

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

5.plot: What secrets are hiding in our map? What's behind the "blank spots" like Area 51? What possessed the citizens of Key West to throw down their margaritas and secede from Florida? And even in the heartland, there are those living on the edge -- in Kansas, old missile bunkers are now five bedroom dream homes. And what about the county in Georgia that was left off the state's quarter?

6.title: Use It or Lose It

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

6.plot: If you thought our borders were set in stone, you'd be wrong. Who stole a corner of Washington, DC? Is Ohio actually a state? And why isn't St. Louis our nation's capital? One thing's for sure -- our map could look very different. How did we create order out of so much chaos? With the vote.

7.title: Church and States

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

7.plot: Ever since the Pilgrims boarded the Mayflower, what we believe and how we believe has shaped the American map. Could Utah have been bigger than Texas? How did religion shatter New England into such odd little shapes? And did the Civil War actually begin... in Kansas?

8.title: Boom with a View

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

8.plot: Did money make our map? Through boom and through bust, the sweet smell of profit has drawn and redrawn our states. How did Green Bay help carve our border with Canada? What does football have to do with fur? Is North Carolina the real "Golden State"? And why should we all move to North Dakota?

9.title: Culture Clash

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

9.plot: Will rivalries within our states break them into pieces? Cultures compete against each other all over the map. In extreme cases, they can divide states in two. How did World War II preserve the shape of California? Will part of Maine break off and become Northern Massachusetts? And as new cultures move into Florida, will the state's cowboy tradition get pushed off the map?

10.title: Mouthing Off

episode of.title: How the States Got Their Shapes (TV Series 2011–2012)

10.plot: We all live in the same country, so why do we sound do different? It's a matter of where you are on the map. Why didn't the southern accent exist until after the Civil War? How did California athletes end up coining so many new words? Why do we have so many different words for the same things -- like pop versus soda?

imdb.plot outline: Follows correspondent Brian Unger as he criss-crosses the country reporting on the tales behind the boundaries. Think: Why does Montana look like it took a bite out of Idaho? Or how are flying fish threatening to re-draw the lines of Illinois?
imdb.title: How the States Got Their Shapes
plot: Follows correspondent Brian Unger as he criss-crosses the country reporting on the tales behind the boundaries. Think: Why does Montana look like it took a bite out of Idaho? Or how are flying fish threatening to re-draw the lines of Illinois?::Anonymous
